questions.text: What is the Windows Registry?
questions.explanation: The Windows Registry is a hierarchical database that stores configuration settings and options in Microsoft Windows.

questions.text: Which registry hive stores settings specific to the local computer?
questions.explanation: HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE (HKLM) stores settings specific to the local computer.

questions.text: The Windows Registry is stored entirely in memory.
questions.explanation: The Windows Registry is stored on disk in files like NTUSER.DAT and USRCLASS.DAT, and loaded into memory at logon.

questions.text: Which registry hive stores settings specific to the currently logged-in user?
questions.explanation: HKEY_CURRENT_USER (HKCU) stores settings specific to the currently logged-in user.

questions.text: Which registry hive contains information about file associations?
questions.explanation: HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT (HKCR) contains information about file associations and OLE Object Class IDs.

questions.text: HKEY_CURRENT_CONFIG stores hardware profile information.
questions.explanation: HKEY_CURRENT_CONFIG acts as a pointer to a registry key that keeps the information about the hardware profile currently being used.

questions.text: Which registry hive contains a SID sub-key for all loaded user profiles?
questions.explanation: HKEY_USERS (HKU) contains a SID sub-key for all loaded user profiles.

questions.text: Which subkey in HKLM contains information about the Windows System setup?
questions.explanation: The SYSTEM subkey in HKLM contains information about the Windows System setup.

questions.text: The SAM subkey in HKLM contains software and Windows settings.
questions.explanation: The SOFTWARE subkey in HKLM contains software and Windows settings. The SAM subkey contains account information.

questions.text: Which subkey in HKLM is linked to the security database of the domain?
questions.explanation: The SECURITY subkey in HKLM is linked to the security database of the domain.

questions.text: What type of information is stored in the NTUSER.DAT file?
questions.explanation: NTUSER.DAT stores user profile settings.

questions.text: The Windows Registry is a flat database.
questions.explanation: The Windows Registry is a hierarchical database.

questions.text: Which tool is commonly used to edit the Windows Registry?
questions.explanation: Regedit is commonly used to edit the Windows Registry.

questions.text: What is the purpose of the USRCLASS.DAT file?
questions.explanation: USRCLASS.DAT stores class registration information for a user.

questions.text: Changes made in HKCU affect all users on the system.
questions.explanation: Changes made in HKCU only affect the currently logged-in user.

questions.text: Which of the following is a valid data type in the Windows Registry?
questions.explanation: REG_DWORD is a valid data type in the Windows Registry.

questions.text: What does SID stand for?
questions.explanation: SID stands for Security Identifier.

questions.text: Each user account has a unique SID.
questions.explanation: Each user account has a unique SID (Security Identifier).

questions.text: Which part of the SID indicates the highest level of authority?
questions.explanation: The ID authority indicates the highest level of authority that can issue SIDs.

questions.text: What is the SID for a DOMAIN ADMINISTRATOR account?
questions.explanation: The SID S-1-5-[4a]-513 is a DOMAIN ADMINISTRATOR Acct.

questions.text: Which registry key contains information about registered applications, such as file associations and OLE Object Class IDs?
questions.explanation: HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT (HKCR) contains information about registered applications, such as file associations and OLE Object Class IDs. Compilation of user-based HKCU\Software\Classes and machine-based HKLM\Software\Classes

questions.text: Which registry key acts as a pointer to the hardware profile currently being used?
questions.explanation: HKEY_CURRENT_CONFIG (HKCC) doesn’t store any information itself, but acts as a pointer, or shortcut, to a registry key that keeps the information about the hardware profile currently being used.

questions.text: In which file are user profile settings stored?
questions.explanation: User profile settings are stored in each user’s NTUSER.DAT and USRCLASS.dat files and are loaded at logon.

questions.text: Which registry key contains a SID sub-key for all loaded (logged in) user profiles?
questions.explanation: HKEY_USERS (HKU) contains a SID sub-key for all loaded (logged in) user profiles. These user profile settings are stored in each user’s NTUSER.DAT and USRCLASS.dat files and are loaded at logon.
